resources.string: This device doesn\'t support Camera2 API.
If you see white light that you can not see by naked eye, it is infrared light.

Worried that the mirror might be two-way? There’s a very simple way to check. “The fingernail test is old but it still works,” says Roberts. “Put a fingernail up against the glass. In a real mirror, you can’t reach your finger in the reflection. But if you can touch your own finger in the reflection, that’s a problem. It’s a strong indication that it’s a two-way mirror.”
The easiest way to detect hidden cameras is checking around the environment carefully. Search carefully would be helpful to spot “obvious” hidden cameras.
If you are searching in public places, avoid times when foot traffic is highest or you could end up drawing a crowd and spending more time answering questions than digging for treasure.
When you’re moving the metal detector in a sweeping motion, be careful to overlap your sweeps so you don’t miss any potential targets.
If you are moving too fast, you might miss something important!

Turn of the lights in your room and turn on the flashlight on your mobile phone and Pan the flashlight around the room. Spot slowly and examine any suspicious. If you notice any reflective lights, there might be a hidden camera.
Analyze the tissue box thoroughly as there are more chances of availability of camera or any suspicios material in the tissue box.
Most of the camera will usually be hidden, but the camera\'s lens must always be visible for the camera to be effective. This means that you can always spot a camera by looking for its lens.

While public cameras tend to be less nefarious and more conspicuous than their personal counterparts, it may be good to know where the nearest \"hidden\" camera is if you\'re attempting to dispute a traffic incident or something similar. You can usually find cameras in the following locations: ATMs Store ceilings Two-way mirrors in stores and high-profile shops (e.g., jewelry fronts) Gas stations Traffic lights
